source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Aizoaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Aizoaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Petaloid staminodes yellow (becoming pink with age); stamens 400–600; dorsal angle of leaves, bracts and larger sepals denticulate in at least the upper half
Petaloid staminodes predominantly pink or purple; stamens c. 400 or fewer; dorsal angle of leaves smooth throughout or denticulate shortly below the apex only

Petaloid staminodes shading to pale near base but not white, streaked brown for virtually their entire width on drying; membranous margins of smaller sepals dotted for more than half their width; leaf length mostly at least 8 times width

Petaloid staminodes white at and near base, if streaked brown when dry, then only narrowly about the midline; membranous margins of smaller sepals dotted for less than half their width; leaf length often less than 7 times width
Styles shortly united near base; petaloid staminodes usually less than 15 mm long; calyx narrowly thickened on outer perimeter at apex; mostly dry and/or inland sites
Styles free for their entire length; petaloid staminodes 15 mm long or more; calyx usually not thickened at apex; mostly coastal
Stamens 300–400, in 4–6 series; leaves commonly glaucous; apparently East Gippsland coasts only
Stamens 100–250, in 3–4 series; leaves green or glaucous; coasts throughout the State and inland north-western Victoria
Petaloid staminodes c. 60; inland sites in north-western Victoria
